awd_titl_txt: Variational Methods for Materials Science and Mathematical Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The mathematical theories and techniques developed in this project provide a foundation for understanding aspects of imaging and of the properties of materials.  The use of self-assembly processes to manufacture modern semiconductor nanostructures, quantum wires, and quantum dots is of pivotal importance in microelectric and optoelectronic technologies, such as reflective or anti-reflective coatings for optics, the fabrication of layers of insulators and semiconductors for integrated circuits, quantum well lasers, and the processing of nanoscale materials.  We address the variational study of relevant observed phenomena in nanowires and in the epitaxial deposition of a thin film onto a substrate.  We study phase nucleation in Lithium-Ion batteries, which are central to advances in portable electronic devices, electric vehicles, and renewable energy storage; phase nucleation is important in understanding charge-discharge dynamics (poor cycle life) and other material limitations of these batteries.  In what concerns the mathematics of imaging, we pursue the analytical investigation of image processing, restoration, and registration, which are fundamental to the advance of computer vision, medical imaging, film restoration, and scanning probe microscopy.  These projects offer opportunities for integrating research in applied analysis with the education of advanced graduate students at the interface between mathematics and the physical sciences and engineering.  Graduate students participate in the research of the project.

What unifies these topics is that underlying energies involve higher order derivatives in spaces with discontinuous admissible fields, multiple scales interact, bulk and surface energies compete, and degeneracy of usually expected properties prevails.  Together, these difficulties prevent the use of well-understood mathematical theories, and require new ideas and the introduction of innovative mathematical tools.  Contemporary methods in the calculus of variations and nonlinear partial differential equations are used to study quasi-static (elliptic) and evolution (parabolic) systems of equations in a range of problems arising in materials science that span epitaxy, batteries, nanowires, and phase transitions.  These methods are combined in novel ways with multi-level (machine learning) training schemes to study models for edge detection, image segmentation, signal denoising and detexturing, joint image segmentation, and image registration.  Graduate students participate in the research of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The scientific objective of this project was the integration of new mathematical tools from the areas of the Calculus of Variations and nonlinear PDEs with scientific discoveries in other disciplines, particularly in materials science and image processing.

This project impacted on sister disciplines by collaborative research, through lectures and special courses, and via publications. The objectives of this proposal were intrinsically related to the identification of leading-edge mathematical questions in materials science and imaging science. In particular:
• mechanics, materials science: epitaxy, dewetting, nanowires, homogenization and magnetoelasticity of high contrast materials, phase transitions, and the gradient flow for homogenization within the Allen-Cahn model;

• variational problems in imaging: multilevel training schemes, image segmentation, and registration.

The educational goals of this project were (i) to train the next generation of leaders in applied analysis cognizant of emerging mathematical areas that underscore contemporary challenges in materials science and imaging science, and which benefit from interdisciplinary interaction and international cooperation; (ii) to attract a diverse cohort of strong graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to this area of the mathematical sciences.

Variational Problems in Materials Science

Convergence of dislocations moving by the gradient flow of the elastic energy to dislocations moving by the gradient flow of the arc-length functional was established. The methods that were developed here are a blueprint for the more physical setting of linearized isotropic elasticity.

A homogenization problem associated with quasi-crystalline multiple integrals was considered, generalizing "classical" results for curl-free fields to the case of fields in the kernel of first- order PDE systems, including Maxwell equations.

Liquid drops were mathematically analyzed for the first time in the context of nanowires.

A series of papers (one published, one accepted, two submitted, one in preparation) initiated the variational study of the interaction between homogenization and phase separation. Different regimes have been considered, and this theme has now been investigated by other groups in the US and Europe, also within the context of stochastic homogenization.

An overview of recent analytical developments in the study of epitaxial growth was presented. Quasistatic equilibrium was established, regularity of solutions is addressed, and the evolution of epitaxial strained elastic films was treated using minimizing movements.

A survey of various mathematical contributions to the behavior of thin films was offered. The common thread was to view thin film behavior as the variational limit of a three-dimensional domain with a related behavior when the thickness of that domain vanishes.

Variational Problems in Imaging Science

A bilevel training scheme was used to introduce a novel class of regularizers, providing a unified approach to standard regularizers.

A main result was the Gamma-convergence of the Ambrosio- Tortorelli approximation of the Mumford-Shah functional for piecewise smooth approximations. Further, it was shown that  the Ambrosio-Tortorelli approximation scheme with weighted underlying metric converges to a Mumford-Shah image segmentation functional depending on the weight.

Regularizations with total variation (TV) and total generalized variation (TGV) are some of the best-known methods in image denoising. They crucially depend on the choice of their tuning parameters. In a series of papers (one submitted, another in preparation) multilevel machine learning training schemes optimizing performance on noisy/clean training image pairs were studied, with space-dependent tuning parameters that are piecewise constant on dyadic grids, with the grid itself being part of the minimization, 

Training and mentoring The PI makes a deliberate effort in attracting young women to work in her area of research in applied analysis, and she has been quite successful at that. The PI's trainees are encouraged to participate in the CNA (Center for Nonlinear Analysis, of which the PI is Director) career development activities, and they are actively involved in the CNA seminars and working groups. The PI ensures the participation of her students and postdocs in conferences, workshops, and schools in the US and abroad, and has encouraged her trainees to secure funding from the organizing committees of these events. In the majority of the cases, they have been successful at obtaining travel awards.

Ph.D. Students Supervised by the PI, and Partially Funded Under this Award:

* Francesco Cassandra, funded under this award on Fall 2021, one Summer month in 2022

Francesco Cassandra is an Italian citizen who started his Ph.D. program at CMU in Fall 2021 under the co-supervision of the PI and her colleague Giovanni Leoni. He already passed 3 out of the 4 written Ph.D. qualifying exams.

* Likhit Ganedi, funded under this award in Fall 2019, three Summer months in 2020, Spring 2021, Spring 2022

Likhit Ganedi is a US citizen, and started a postdoc at Aachen University (Germany) in Fall 2022.

* Kerrek Stinson, funded under this award in Spring 2020 and Fall 2020

Kerrek Stinson is a US citizen, and started a postdoc appointment at the University of Bonn in Fall 2021.
